metadata.title: Effect of Ⅲ B metals (Sc, Y, La and Ce) on active components regulation of VPO catalyst in <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-butane selective oxidation

Effect of Ⅲ B metals (Sc, Y, La and Ce) on active components regulation of VPO catalyst in n-butane selective oxidation Wenjiao Li Methodology Investigation Writing – original draft a b Shupeng Guo Formal analysis Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Heqin Guo Formal analysis Writing – review & editing Data curation Resources a Yong Xiao Software Project administration a Litao Jia Supervision Project administration a c ⁎ Debao Li Supervision Project administration a c a State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, Shanxi, PR China State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan Shanxi 030001 PR China aState Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, Shanxi, PR China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, PR China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 PR China bUniversity of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, PR China c Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian, 116023, PR China Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy Dalian 116023 PR China cDalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Dalian, 116023, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Vanadium phosphorus oxide (VPO) catalyst has been modified by the Ⅲ B elements (Sc, Y, La, Ce) have been prepared. Those catalysts were tested in n-butane selective oxidation, and it was shown that Y-VPO catalyst has the highest maleic anhydride (MA) yield among the studied catalysts. The VPO catalyst was characterized by a series of techniques. As evidenced by property characterization in conjunction with catalytic performance, we found that the presence of rare earth metals alters the phase composition of VPO catalyst. And then, the acidity of VPO catalyst was adjusted. Finally, the change of acidity could impact the n-butane activation process, which affected the n-butane conversion. Moreover, the rare earth metals also modulated the ratio of lattice oxygen and surface oxygen and then the MA selectivity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Rare earth metal VPO catalyst N-butane oxidation MA Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction MA is a high-value-added compound that is mostly produced through the selective oxidation of n-butane [1,2]. Despite being shown to the most efficient industrial catalyst for the selective oxidation of n-butane, VPO catalyst has been demonstrated to be vulnerable to peroxidation, making controlling MA selectivity problematic. The molar yield of MA is remains quite low limited by the selectivity [3–5], which fails to meet the industrial requirements [3,6,7]. As a result, understanding the essential features of VPO catalyst through some ways is critical in order to identify methods for optimizing VPO catalyst. So far, great efforts have been devoted to modifying VPO catalyst to improve MA yield and better understand catalytic behavior. The main methods to optimize catalyst include the development of new catalyst preparation methods and the regulation of catalyst surface properties by the addition of promoters [6,8-34]. Among them, the addition of metal dopants is currently recognized as the most direct and effective way. At present, various metals have been used to modify VPO catalyst, such as Zr, Zn, Mo, Bi, Ni, Mn, Fe, Cu, Co, Ga, Nb, Ce, Cr, Y, Au, Sm, Te, La, etc. [8,12,13,15,23,33-46]. Despite many studies, there is still no consensus on the understanding of the active sites and surface properties of catalyst. The complex structure of VPO catalyst is the primary cause of this condition. The complex VPO catalyst has been found in more than 14 phases with distinguished structural morphology and changeable surface chemical states and so on [26,47]. Therefore, plenty of opportunities exist in the field to optimize the VPO catalyst composition and improve catalytic performance. The understanding of the reaction mechanism can help us optimize the VPO catalyst. The reaction conforms to the REDOX mechanism. In short, n-butane is first dehydrogenated to form butene or butadiene, and then MA is formed by the epoxide of three oxygen atoms. The rate-controlled step is the process of dehydrogenation step for the reaction. Therefore, we need to accelerate the step of activating CH bond, and then accelerate the dehydrogenation process. Many researches show that rare earth metals (Sc, Y La, Ce,) is often used as promoters or supports to enhance the catalytic performance of low carbon alkanes dehydrogenation [20,48]. Shang et al. [49] investigated the impact of Scandium (Sc) on catalytic performance for the propane dehydrogenation reaction. And they found the introduce of Sc promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies and active sites, thus enhancing the catalytic performance evidently. Zhang et al. [50] synthesized La-doped mesoporous alumina for propane dehydrogenation, and the substance served as the support of platinum–tin catalyst. The outcome demonstrated that adding La improves the efficiency of the catalytic process. This might be due to introduction of La encouraged the distribution of metallic particles. In addition, ZnAl2O4 modified by Y, La, Ce was used to support PtSn and the catalyst was tested in isobutane dehydrogenation process [51]. The three metals incorporate into ZnAl2O4 matrix in different ways and affect the acidity of the support. The positive role of Sc, Y La, Ce in the dehydrogenation oxidation of alkanes was observed. Combined with the requirement of the active sites and the essential nature of promoters Sc, Y La, Ce, modifying VPO catalyst with Sc, Y La, Ce is a good way to explore the catalytic mechanism. Furthermore, to the best of our knowledge, no research has been conducted on the use of congener rare earth metals as modifiers to enhance the catalytic performance. With the above considerations, this work attempts to use the Ⅲ B elements to modify VPO catalyst. The catalytic performance in relation to the effects of various metal additions on the VPO catalyst is studied systematically. The relationship between the catalytic activity and the performance characteristics of VPO catalyst modified by the III B metal elements were proposed to be related. Experimental section Catalysts synthesis methods The bulk VPO precursor (PVPO) and VPO precursors modified by metals (M-PVPO) were obtained as the literature [34]. The preparation process is as follows: V2O5 was dissolved in a mixture of isobutanol and benzyl alcohol. Phosphoric acid was added to the mixture after reflux. After further reflux, the resulting solution was filtered, washed and dried. The M-PVPO is prepared by adding a certain amount of ScN3O9·6H2O, YN3O9·6H2O, LaN3O9·6H2O and CeN3O9·6H2O with V2O5 in the first step, respectively. The M/V atomic ratio is 0.01. The obtained powders are denoted as M-PVPO (M=Sc, Y, La and Ce). The bulk VPO catalyst and metal-modified VPO (M-VPO) catalysts were prepared in the method [34]: the PVPO and M-PVPO were formed into purpose particles (20–40 mesh). Afterwards, precursor enclosed in a quartz tube was activated in-situ. Raising the temperature to 430 °C in the mixture gas of 1.1% n-butane in air and keep the temperature for a period of time. Correspondingly, the obtained powders were named as bulk VPO catalyst and M-VPO (M= Sc, Y, La and Ce) catalyst. Characterization methods TG is conducted on a SETSYS EVOLUTION TGA 16/18 thermal analyzer. The TG and DTG of all precursors are measured. XRD analyzer (PANalytical X'pert3) with monochromatized CuKα radiation is used to determine the structural characteristics of all precursors and catalysts. With the use of the LabRAM HR Evolution Raman equipment, Raman spectra are captured. The excitation source is the Ar ion laser's 325 nm line. The morphological of all precursors and catalysts are obtained by a SEM device (JSM-7900F) with an acceleration voltage of 5 kV. In order to obtain the information of the textural properties of catalyst, a MicroActive ASAP 2460 devices are carried out. AXIS ULTRADLD XPS is used to examine the chemical characteristics. XPSPEAK41 software is used to fit the O 1 s and V 2p3/2 spectra of all samples. The peaks are resolved using model functions with 90% Gaussian and 10% Lorentzian. The H2-TPR experiments are measured by multipurpose automatic adsorption instrument (FINESORB-3010D). The activated VPO catalyst is pretreated of 1 h at 100°C in Ar atmosphere. The sample is then cooled to room temperature. Subsequently, in a 5% H2/Ar gas the catalyst is heated to 850°C until the reduction was complete. TCD detector is used to recorded the consumption of H2. The elements content on the VPO catalyst surface is calibrated by the standard of reduction of CuO. NH3-TPD is performed by XIANQUAN5080B. The activated catalyst (100 mg) is pre-treated for 1 h in He atmosphere at 200°C. The catalyst is cooled to room temperature. Then the obtained sample is adsorbed in 10% NH3/He mixture. Finally, the sample is heated to 500°C in He air. The exhaled gas was detected by TCD detector. Catalyst test methods The selective oxidation of n-butane was tested in a continuous flow fixed bed reactor. After in situ activation, the VPO catalyst of 20–40 mush continued to react under activation conditions, and the outlet gas generated was analyzed by online chromatography. Carbon mass balances were better than 95% typically. Results and discussion Characterization results of catalysts Fig. 1 presents the SEM micrographs of the PVPO (a) and VPO catalysts (b). It shows that the bulk VPO precursor exhibits the flaky platelets, while the Sc-, Y-, La- and Ce-modified precursors exhibits rosette plate-like structure. The bulk VPO, La-VPO and Sc-VPO catalysts presents a disordered stacked blocky structure, while the Sc- and Y-modified catalysts still maintain the hierarchical structure. TG analysis and DTA are depicted in Fig. 1(c). From Fig. 1(c), the weight loss curves underwent three steps for all catalysts [11,52,53]. The first two step occurs at 150 and 350°C [34,53]. The former arises from the desorption of physically adsorbed water. The latter originates from the elimination of alcohols from the precursor layers and the conversion of VOHPO4·0·5H2O to (VO)2P2O7. Crystal defects may be the cause of the third stage above 430 °C [52,53]. The decomposition temperature of all M-PVPO is higher than bulk VPO precursor. And the decomposition temperature of Y-PVPO and Sc-PVPO is relatively high. That may lead to the Y-PVPO and Sc-PVPO maintain a good morphology after activation. The result and the SEM findings are in good accord. To further investigate the difference in catalyst structure, the crystallographic structure of all the PVPO and VPO catalysts are analyzed through XRD and Raman. The XRD patterns of all PVPO and all VPO catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 (a) and (b). Fig. 2(a) illustrates that all the PVPO exhibit the characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ=15.8°, 19.9°, 24.5°, 27.3°, 30.7°, corresponding to the (001), (101), (021), (121) and (220) planes of VOHPO4 0·0·5H2O [21,27,54], respectively. Fig. 2(b) demonstrates that the main peaks at 2θ=18.4°, 23°, 28.6° and 30.0°, which are related to the (020), (200), (024) and (032) planes of (VO)2P2O7 [43,54], respectively. Interestingly, the predominant crystalline phase for the bulk VPO catalyst is (VO)2P2O7 phase. However, the peaks assigned to VOPO4 phase are detected for Sc-, Y-, La-, Ce-VPO catalysts. The peaks are assigned to the characteristic peaks of δ-VOPO4 phase [21], αⅡ-VOPO4 phase at 22.3° and 24.4° as well as 25.1° and 29.2° [27]. According to the literatures [22,39,41,45], the (VO)2P2O7 (200) surface is the active plane of VPO catalyst. The plane is topologically transformed from the VOHPO4 0·0·5H2O (001) surface. The relative strength of the (001) surface is consistent with the exposure of the surface (220). Therefore, Table 1 lists the I(001)/I(220) of PVPO and I(200)/I(024) ratio of VPO catalysts. Raman spectra of all PVPO and the activated VPO catalysts give more information about the crystal structure. As shown in Fig. 2(c) and (d), the main bands of all precursors emerged at 986, 1106, 1053 cm−1 are attributed to VOHPO4·0·5H2O [22]. It was reported that VOPO4 phases are found in the band at 468, 598, 941, 1018, and 1090 cm−1, whereas (VO)2P2O7 phase are found at 443, 467, 588, and 1016 cm−1. The emergence of novel VOPO4 phases for Sc-, Y-, La- and Ce-VPO catalysts. Novel VOPO4 phases were ascribed to the β-VOPO4 phase (443 and 467 cm−1), the αⅡ-VOPO4 or δ-VOPO4 phase (1016 cm−1), as well as the γ-VOPO4 or αⅡ-VOPO4 phase (1090 cm−1) [7,30,55]. According to the literatures, the formation of MA is mainly affected by the V5+ phase [7,12,40,44,46,56-59]. A certain amount of δ-VOPO4 phase promoted the formation of MA, while αII-VOPO4 phase inhibited the formation of MA [44,56]. Of course, it is also suggested that the presence of β-VOPO4 phases can enhance the catalytic activity and promote the n-butane conversion [12,46,54,59]. The XRD and Raman results suggest that the introduce of rare earth metal facilitates the formation of δ-VOPO4 phase, as well as the potential formation of αII-VOPO4 phase and β-VOPO4 phases. Therefore, the rare earth modified VPO catalyst is likely to affect the selective oxidation. H2-TPR experiments are carried out to learn more about the vanadium oxidation state and the different oxygen species. Fig. 3 shows the TPR spectra of all activated VPO catalysts. Fig. 3 shows that all catalysts exhibit two major peaks in the region of 493–521°C and 745–768°C, respectively [23,24,29,46]. Generally, the reduction of lattice oxygen caused by the V5+ and V4+ phase can be attributed to the peaks at lower and higher temperatures, respectively [5,22]. For bulk VPO catalyst, the first peak appears at 521°C, which shift to lower temperature for modified VPO catalysts. The result means that it is easy to be reduced for the V5+ phase of modified VPO catalysts. The total reduction property of all activated catalysts from TPR results are listed in Table 2 . It can be observed that the oxygen atoms removal ratio of V5+/V4+ decreases for Sc-, Y-modified catalysts. While that almost unchanged for La-, Ce-modified catalysts. XPS measurements are furthermore performed to obtain more information about the surface element chemical states. The V 2p3/2 peak at 517.4 and 518.7 eV is typically associated with the V4+ and V5+ phase [32,34], respectively. VPO catalyst is a mixture of V4+ and V5+ phase from Fig. 4 (a). The V5+/V4+ ratio is calculated (Table 3 ). As summarized in Table 3, the surface V5+/V4+ atomic ratio of Sc-, Y-modified VPO catalysts decreases, while that for La-, Ce-modified VPO catalysts increases. The results illustrate that the introduce of rare earth metals can modify the surface vanadium oxidation state distribution. The oxygen species on the catalysts surface can be estimated furthermore by XPS. The lattice oxygen and hydroxide ions as well as carbonates is key to VPO catalyst, which is denoted Lat-O and Sur-O, respectively. As indicated in Fig. 4(b), the peaks at 531.0–533.0 eV are ascribed to Lat-O in VPO catalyst, while the peak at 533.0–534.1 eV is ascribed to Sur-O in VPO catalyst [23,29]. The ratio of Lat-O/Sur-O are listed in Table 3. The value increases significantly with the addition of Sc, Y and La. All VPO catalysts have a P-enriched surface, which is a good phenomenon for typical VPO catalyst. It is well known that the enrichment of a certain of P element can improve the catalytic activity [31]. This is because a certain P element enriched on the surface can help to stabilize the active phase and adjust the V5+/V4+ ratio [6,42,43]. It was reported that the surface acidity on catalyst is crucial for the n-butane selective oxidation. Therefore, NH3-TPD is performed to investigate the surface acidity. As seen in Fig. 5 , all the catalysts show three desorption peaks. According to the location of the peak, it can be divided into three acid sites with different intensity. The distribution of surface acid site on VPO catalyst are calculated in Table 4 . As compared to the bulk VPO catalyst, the overall acid sites for Sc- and Y-VPO catalysts decrease. While there is no noticeable variation in total acid sites for La-, Ce-VPO catalysts. Interestingly, it is found that the change of acid sites for the VPO catalyst is in good agreement with the change of V5+phase by XPS and NH3-TPD result. Therefore, it can be possibly concluded that the V5+phase of the catalyst may have contributed to its acidity. So, the relationship between the acid sites and the V5+/V4+ ratio is studied. The correlation between the acid sites and the V5+/V4+ ratio is illustrated in Fig. 6 . Noticeably, it can be seen that the weak and medium acid sites have been proposed to have a significant positive correlation with the V5+/V4+ ratio on VPO catalyst surface, as shown in Fig. 6(a) and (b). Thus, it can be concluded that the V5+/V4+ ratio is the key factor to increasement of the weak and medium acid sites. Catalytic performance The catalytic evaluation for all activated VPO catalysts is carried out in n-butane selective oxidation to MA (see Table 5 ). The bulk VPO catalyst has shown a n-butane conversion of 85.61% and a MA selectivity of 49.12%. Sc-VPO catalyst could significantly improve n-butane conversion when compared to bulk VPO catalyst. Y-VPO catalyst could improve both conversion and selectivity simultaneously. However, La-VPO catalyst slightly increases MA selectivity but at the cost of decreasing conversion. Ce-VPO catalyst reduces conversion and selectivity simultaneously. Among the researched catalysts, the MA yield of 56.28% is achieved on Y-modified VPO catalyst. The findings of the characterization demonstrate that the introduce of rare earth metals considerably alters the phase composition and surface characteristics of catalyst. The introduction of rare earth metals leads to the appearance of δ-, αII- and β-VOPO4 phases in VPO catalyst. The change of VOPO4 phase may be associated with the surface acidity on catalyst. The change of the surface acidity might affect the n-butane dehydrogenation. It is suggested that the suitable amount of VOPO4 phase for Sc-VPO and Y-VPO catalysts result in the suitable the surface acidity, and then result in the high n-butane conversion. Moreover, Y-VPO and La-VPO catalysts show the high MA selectivity because of the selective δ-VOPO4 phase. Discussion As previously mentioned, the weak and medium acidities could be caused by the VOPO4 phase on catalyst. Thus, to try further investigate the impact of surface acid sites on catalytic performance, the relationship between the acid sites and n-butane conversion is explored. As shown in Fig. 7 (a) and (b), the weak and medium acid sites have been proposed to have a negative correlation with the conversion of n-butane. Typically, surface acidity can regulate the adsorption and desorption behavior of n-butane [30,33]. In conclusion, the introduction of rare earth metals leads to the change of V5+ phase, further adjusts the acidity of catalyst, and finally affects the catalytic performance. From XRD and Raman results, there is the formation of new V5+ phases for the M-VPO catalysts. This might indicate that these VPO catalysts promote the diversity of V5+ phases. A certain amount of δ-VOPO4 and β-VOPO4 phase can enhance the activity of VPO catalyst, while αII-VOPO4 phase inhibited the formation of MA [12,46,54,59]. The introduction of rare earth metal may also encourage the creation of the δ-, αII- and β-VOPO4 phases. The H2-TPR and XPS data, however, demonstrate that V5+ phase for Sc, Y-VPO catalysts decrease, while slightly increase for La, Ce-VPO catalysts. Frey et al. [57] demonstrated that n-butane is preferentially adsorbed and activated at sites of δ-VOPO4 phase by quantitative solid-state NMR investigation. Thus, it can be guessed that the addition of Sc and Y moderately increases the δ-VOPO4 phase of VPO catalyst and promotes the activation of n-butane. The introduce of La and Ce can promote the increase of non-selective phase or generate excessive V5+ phase, so their catalytic performance is not satisfactory. Notably, the Sc-VPO and Y-VPO catalysts present higher activity than bulk VPO catalyst, while the La-VPO and Ce-VPO catalysts do not. The activity of VPO catalyst is influenced by several factors. The value of Lat-O/Sur-O ratio for Sc- and Y-VPO catalysts significantly increases. According to our previously study [34], the lattice oxygen from VPO catalyst may promote the process of MA synthesis. Additionally, it is believed that the ratio value of P/V really isn't the most crucial element in determining the catalytic effectiveness of catalyst. Besides, from the SEM and TG results, the structure stability of Sc-PVPO and Y-PVPO catalysts is enhanced. And the bulk VPO possesses plate-like structure, while Sc-VPO and Y-VPO catalysts possess rosette-shape clusters. The rosette-shaped clusters can expose the (200) plane preferentially, which is favorable for MA synthesis [45]. Conclusion In summary, a series of VPO catalysts modified by rare earth metals (Sc, Y, La, and Ce) are prepared. Sc, Y-VPO catalysts show an obvious improvement in n-butane conversion. La, Ce-VPO catalysts show an increase in MA selectivity. Among all used catalysts, Y-VPO catalyst have the highest MA yield. Combined with all the characterization, the reason is analyzed. Firstly, the V5+/V4+ ratio of Y-VPO catalyst decreases compared with bulk VPO catalyst. Then, the acidity of catalyst deceases due to the decrease of the V5+/V4+ on the catalyst surface. Finally, the conversion of n-butane is encouraged by the proper surface acidity. Additionally, the Lat-O/Sur-O ratio has a significant impact on MA selectivity. Thus, Y-VPO catalyst have the highest MA yield in this study because of the increases in both n-butane conversion and MA selectivity simultaneously. coredata.dc:description: Vanadium phosphorus oxide (VPO) catalyst has been modified by the Ⅲ B elements (Sc, Y, La, Ce) have been prepared. Those catalysts were tested in n-butane selective oxidation, and it was shown that Y-VPO catalyst has the highest maleic anhydride (MA) yield among the studied catalysts. The VPO catalyst was characterized by a series of techniques. As evidenced by property characterization in conjunction with catalytic performance, we found that the presence of rare earth metals alters the phase composition of VPO catalyst. And then, the acidity of VPO catalyst was adjusted. Finally, the change of acidity could impact the n-butane activation process, which affected the n-butane conversion. Moreover, the rare earth metals also modulated the ratio of lattice oxygen and surface oxygen and then the MA selectivity.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of Ⅲ B metals (Sc, Y, La and Ce) on active components regulation of VPO catalyst in n-butane selective oxidation
